newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Slovenia's Salus H1 profit down on lower margins.
newsitem.headline: Slovenia's Salus H1 profit down on lower margins.

text.p: Slovenian drugs wholesaler Salus on Wednesday reported a drop in first-half net profit to 243.1 million tolars ($1.83 million) from 353.1 million tolars in the same period last year.
"The main reason for the fall in profit was the government's reduction of trade margins for pharmaceutical trading companies," chief executive Igor Jenko said.
Salus' turnover for the six months to June 30 rose to 4.9 billion tolars ($ 37.3 million) from 4.8 billion in 1995.
The company said the half-year dividend would remain unchanged at 500 tolars ($3.8) per share.
Salus' shares have risen 14.6 percent since August 27 when the Ljubljana district court found Salus not guilty of a faulty privatisation process. The shares closed at 14,625 tolars on Tuesday.
In February Salus appealed against a decision by the Slovenian Payment Agency requiring it to give the state an 80-percent stake in the company.
The agency said formerly state-owned Salus incorrectly transferred state capital to its newly established subsidiary Finsa in 1991.
The state does not currently own any part of Salus. -- Novica Mihajlovic, Ljubljana newsroom, 386-61-125-8439
